new.ruleText: The energy symbol is {E}. It represents one energy counter. To pay {E}, a player removes one energy counter from himself or herself.

old.ruleText: The source of damage is the object that dealt it. If an effect requires a player to choose a source of damage, he or she may choose a permanent; a spell on the stack (including a permanent spell); any object referred to by an object on the stack, by a prevention or replacement effect that’s waiting to apply, or by a delayed triggered ability that’s waiting to trigger (even if that object is no longer in the zone it used to be in); old_start or, in certain casual variant games, old_end a face–up old_start card old_end in the command zone. A source doesn’t need to be capable of dealing damage to be a legal choice. See rule 609.7, “Sources of Damage.”

new.ruleText: The source of damage is the object that dealt it. If an effect requires a player to choose a source of damage, he or she may choose a permanent; a spell on the stack (including a permanent spell); any object referred to by an object on the stack, by a prevention or replacement effect that’s waiting to apply, or by a delayed triggered ability that’s waiting to trigger (even if that object is no longer in the zone it used to be in); new_start or new_end a face–up new_start object new_end in the command zone. A source doesn’t need to be capable of dealing damage to be a legal choice. See rule 609.7, “Sources of Damage.”

old.ruleText: Artifacts have their own unique set of subtypes; these subtypes are called artifact types. The artifact types are Clue, Contraption, Equipment (see rule 301.5), old_start and old_end Fortification (see rule 301.6).

new.ruleText: Artifacts have their own unique set of subtypes; these subtypes are called artifact types. The artifact types are Clue, Contraption, Equipment (see rule 301.5), Fortification (see rule 301.6), and Vehicle (see rule 301.7).

old.ruleText: Planeswalkers have their own unique set of subtypes; these subtypes are called planeswalker types. The planeswalker types are Ajani, Arlinn, Ashiok, Bolas, Chandra, Dack, Daretti, Domri, Elspeth, Freyalise, Garruk, Gideon, Jace, Karn, Kaya, Kiora, Koth, Liliana, Nahiri, Narset, Nissa, Nixilis, Ral, Sarkhan, Sorin, Tamiyo, Teferi, Tezzeret, Tibalt, Ugin, Venser, Vraska, and Xenagos. If a player controls two or more planeswalkers that share a planeswalker type, that player chooses one of them, and the rest are put into their owners’ graveyards. This “planeswalker uniqueness rule” is a state–based action. See rule 704.

new.ruleText: Planeswalkers have their own unique set of subtypes; these subtypes are called planeswalker types. The planeswalker types are Ajani, Arlinn, Ashiok, Bolas, Chandra, Dack, Daretti, Domri, new_start Dovin, new_end Elspeth, Freyalise, Garruk, Gideon, Jace, Karn, Kaya, Kiora, Koth, Liliana, Nahiri, Narset, Nissa, Nixilis, Ral, new_start Saheeli, new_end Sarkhan, Sorin, Tamiyo, Teferi, Tezzeret, Tibalt, Ugin, Venser, Vraska, and Xenagos. If a player controls two or more planeswalkers that share a planeswalker type, that player chooses one of them, and the rest are put into their owners’ graveyards. This “planeswalker uniqueness rule” is a state–based action. See rule 704.

old.ruleText: Creatures and tribals share their lists of subtypes; these subtypes are called creature types. The creature types are Advisor, Ally, Angel, Antelope, Ape, Archer, Archon, Artificer, Assassin, Assembly–Worker, Atog, Aurochs, Avatar, Badger, Barbarian, Basilisk, Bat, Bear, Beast, Beeble, Berserker, Bird, Blinkmoth, Boar, Bringer, Brushwagg, Camarid, Camel, Caribou, Carrier, Cat, Centaur, Cephalid, Chimera, Citizen, Cleric, Cockatrice, Construct, Coward, Crab, Crocodile, Cyclops, Dauthi, Demon, Deserter, Devil, Djinn, Dragon, Drake, Dreadnought, Drone, Druid, Dryad, Dwarf, Efreet, Elder, Eldrazi, Elemental, Elephant, Elf, Elk, Eye, Faerie, Ferret, Fish, Flagbearer, Fox, Frog, Fungus, Gargoyle, Germ, Giant, Gnome, Goat, Goblin, God, Golem, Gorgon, Graveborn, Gremlin, Griffin, Hag, Harpy, Hellion, Hippo, Hippogriff, Homarid, Homunculus, Horror, Horse, Hound, Human, Hydra, Hyena, Illusion, Imp, Incarnation, Insect, Jellyfish, Juggernaut, Kavu, Kirin, Kithkin, Knight, Kobold, Kor, Kraken, Lamia, Lammasu, Leech, Leviathan, Lhurgoyf, Licid, Lizard, Manticore, Masticore, Mercenary, Merfolk, Metathran, Minion, Minotaur, Mole, Monger, Mongoose, Monk, Moonfolk, Mutant, Myr, Mystic, Naga, Nautilus, Nephilim, Nightmare, Nightstalker, Ninja, Noggle, Nomad, Nymph, Octopus, Ogre, Ooze, Orb, Orc, Orgg, Ouphe, Ox, Oyster, Pegasus, Pentavite, Pest, Phelddagrif, Phoenix, Pincher, Pirate, Plant, Praetor, Prism, Processor, Rabbit, Rat, Rebel, Reflection, Rhino, Rigger, Rogue, Sable, Salamander, Samurai, Sand, Saproling, Satyr, Scarecrow, Scion, Scorpion, Scout, Serf, Serpent, Shade, Shaman, Shapeshifter, Sheep, Siren, Skeleton, Slith, Sliver, Slug, Snake, Soldier, Soltari, Spawn, Specter, Spellshaper, Sphinx, Spider, Spike, Spirit, Splinter, Sponge, Squid, Squirrel, Starfish, Surrakar, Survivor, Tetravite, Thalakos, Thopter, Thrull, Treefolk, Triskelavite, Troll, Turtle, Unicorn, Vampire, Vedalken, Viashino, Volver, Wall, Warrior, Weird, Werewolf, Whale, Wizard, Wolf, Wolverine, Wombat, Worm, Wraith, Wurm, Yeti, Zombie, and Zubera.

old.ruleText: A noncreature permanent has no power or toughness, even if it’s a card with a power and toughness printed on it (such as a old_start Licid that’s become an Aura). old_end

new.ruleText: A noncreature permanent has no power or toughness, even if it’s a card with a power and toughness printed on it (such as a new_start Vehicle). new_end
If an effect would be created that affects the power and/or toughness of a noncreature permanent, that effect is created even though it doesn’t do anything unless that permanent becomes a creature.
If a creature somehow has no value for its power, its power is 0. The same is true for toughness.
Some artifacts have the subtype “Vehicle.” Vehicles have a crew ability, which allows them to become artifact creatures. See rule 702.121, “Crew.”
Each Vehicle has a printed power and toughness, but it has these characteristics only if it’s also a creature. See rule 208.3.

If a Vehicle becomes a creature, it immediately has its printed power and toughness. Other effects, including the effect that makes it a creature, may modify these values or set them to different values.

old.ruleText: If an object would move from one zone to another, determine what event is moving the object. If the object is moving to a public zone, old_start all players look old_end at it to see if it has any abilities that would affect the move. Then any appropriate replacement effects, whether they come from that object or from elsewhere, are applied to that event. If any effects or rules try to do two or more contradictory or mutually exclusive things to a particular object, that object’s controller–or its owner if it has no controller–chooses which effect to apply, and what that effect does. (Note that multiple instances of the same thing may be mutually exclusive; for example, two simultaneous “destroy” effects.) Then the event moves the object.

new.ruleText: If an object would move from one zone to another, determine what event is moving the object. If the object is moving to a public new_start zone and its owner will be able to look at it in that new_end zone, new_start its owner looks new_end at it to see if it has any abilities that would affect the move. new_start If the object is moving to the battlefield, each other player who will be able to look at it in that zone does so. new_end Then any appropriate replacement effects, whether they come from that object or from elsewhere, are applied to that event. If any effects or rules try to do two or more contradictory or mutually exclusive things to a particular object, that object’s controller–or its owner if it has no controller–chooses which effect to apply, and what that effect does. (Note that multiple instances of the same thing may be mutually exclusive; for example, two simultaneous “destroy” effects.) Then the event moves the object.

When a phase or step begins, any abilities that trigger “at the beginning of” that phase or step trigger. They are put on the stack the next time a player would receive priority. (See rule 116, “Timing and Priority.”)
The upkeep step has no turn–based actions. Once it begins, the active player gets priority. (See rule 116, “Timing and Priority.”)

old.ruleText: old_start Second, old_end any abilities that old_start trigger old_end at the beginning of old_start combat go on old_end the old_start stack. old_end (See rule 603, “Handling Triggered Abilities.”)

new.ruleText: new_start Any abilities that triggered during the untap step and new_end any abilities that new_start triggered new_end at the beginning of the new_start upkeep are put onto the stack before the active player gets priority; the order in which they triggered doesn’t matter. new_end (See rule 603, “Handling Triggered Abilities.”)

old.ruleText: Second, old_start any abilities that trigger at old_end the old_start beginning of the draw step old_end and old_start any other abilities that have triggered go on the stack. old_end

new.ruleText: Second, the new_start active player gets priority. (See rule 116, “Timing new_end and new_start Priority.”) new_end
Second, the active player gets priority. (See rule 116, “Timing and Priority.”)

old.ruleText: The main phase is the only phase in which a player can normally cast artifact, creature, enchantment, planeswalker, and sorcery spells. old_start Only the old_end active player may cast these spells.

new.ruleText: The main phase is the only phase in which a player can normally cast artifact, creature, enchantment, planeswalker, and sorcery spells. new_start The new_end active player may cast these spells.
Second, the active player gets priority. (See rule 116, “Timing and Priority.”)
Any abilities that trigger on attackers being declared trigger.

old.ruleText: Second, the active player gets priority. old_start Players may cast spells old_end and old_start activate abilities. old_end

new.ruleText: Second, the active player gets priority. new_start (See rule 116, “Timing new_end and new_start Priority.”) new_end

old.ruleText: old_start Second, any old_end abilities that triggered on attackers being declared old_start go on old_end the old_start stack. old_end (See rule 603, “Handling Triggered Abilities.”)

new.ruleText: new_start Any new_end abilities that triggered on attackers being declared new_start or that triggered during new_end the new_start process described in rules 508.1 are put onto the stack before the active player gets priority; the order in which they triggered doesn’t matter. new_end (See rule 603, “Handling Triggered Abilities.”)

old.ruleText: A creature that’s put onto the battlefield old_start blocking old_end isn’t affected by requirements or restrictions that apply to the declaration of old_start blockers. old_end

new.ruleText: A creature that’s put onto the battlefield new_start attacking new_end isn’t affected by requirements or restrictions that apply to the declaration of new_start attackers. new_end
Any abilities that trigger on blockers being declared trigger. See rule 509.4 for more information.

old.ruleText: Fourth, the active player gets priority. old_start Players may cast spells old_end and old_start activate abilities. old_end

new.ruleText: Fourth, the active player gets priority. new_start (See rule 116, “Timing new_end and new_start Priority.”) new_end

old.ruleText: old_start Fourth, any old_end abilities that triggered on blockers being declared old_start go on old_end the old_start stack. old_end (See rule 603, “Handling Triggered Abilities.”)

new.ruleText: new_start Any new_end abilities that triggered on blockers being declared new_start or that triggered during new_end the new_start process described in rules 509.1–3 are put onto the stack before the active player gets priority; the order in which they triggered doesn’t matter. new_end (See rule 603, “Handling Triggered Abilities.”)
Triggered abilities that trigger during the declare blockers step may have different trigger conditions.

old.ruleText: A creature that’s put onto the battlefield old_start attacking old_end isn’t affected by requirements or restrictions that apply to the declaration of old_start attackers. old_end

new.ruleText: A creature that’s put onto the battlefield new_start blocking new_end isn’t affected by requirements or restrictions that apply to the declaration of new_start blockers. new_end

old.ruleText: old_start Fifth, old_end the active player gets priority. old_start Players may cast spells old_end and old_start activate abilities. old_end

new.ruleText: new_start Third, new_end the active player gets priority. new_start (See rule 116, “Timing new_end and new_start Priority.”) new_end

old.ruleText: old_start Third, any old_end abilities that triggered on damage being old_start assigned old_end or old_start dealt go on old_end the old_start stack. old_end (See rule 603, “Handling Triggered Abilities.”)

new.ruleText: new_start Any new_end abilities that triggered on damage being new_start dealt new_end or new_start while state–based actions are performed afterward are put onto new_end the new_start stack before the active player gets priority; the order in which they triggered doesn’t matter. new_end (See rule 603, “Handling Triggered Abilities.”)

old.ruleText: old_start First, all “at old_end end of old_start combat” abilities trigger and go on old_end the old_start stack. old_end (See rule 603, “Handling Triggered Abilities.”)

new.ruleText: new_start The new_end end of new_start combat step has no turn–based actions. Once it begins, new_end the new_start active player gets priority. new_end (See rule 116, “Timing and Priority.”)
Abilities that trigger “at end of combat” trigger as the end of combat damage step begins. Abilities that last “until end of combat” expire at the end of the combat phase.
The end step has no turn–based actions. Once it begins, the active player gets priority. (See rule 116, “Timing and Priority.”)

old.ruleText: old_start First, all old_end abilities that trigger “at the beginning of the end step” or “at the beginning of the next end old_start step” go on the stack. (See rule 603, “Handling Triggered Abilities.”) old_end

new.ruleText: new_start Previously, new_end abilities that new_start triggered at the beginning of the end step were printed with the new_end trigger new_start condition “at end of turn.” Cards that were printed with that text have received errata in the Oracle card reference to say new_end “at the beginning of the end step” or “at the beginning of the next end new_start step.” new_end

old.ruleText: If the spell is modal, the player announces the mode choice (see rule 700.2). If the player wishes to splice any cards onto the spell (see rule 702.46), he or she reveals those cards in his or her hand. If the spell has alternative or additional costs that will be paid as it’s being cast such as buyback or kicker costs (see rules 117.8 and 117.9), the player announces his or her intentions to pay any or all of those costs (see rule 601.2f). A player can’t apply two alternative methods of casting or two alternative costs to a single spell. If the spell has a variable cost that will be paid as it’s being cast (such as an {X} in its mana cost; see rule 107.3), the player announces the value of that variable. If a cost that will be paid as the spell is being cast includes hybrid mana symbols, the player announces the nonhybrid equivalent cost he or she intends to pay. If a cost that will be paid as the spell is being cast includes Phyrexian mana symbols, the player announces whether he or she intends to pay 2 life or the corresponding colored mana cost for each of those symbols. Previously made choices (such as choosing to cast a spell with flashback from a graveyard or choosing to cast a creature with morph face down) may restrict the player’s options when making these choices.

new.ruleText: If the spell is modal, the player announces the mode choice (see rule 700.2). If the player wishes to splice any cards onto the spell (see rule 702.46), he or she reveals those cards in his or her hand. If the spell has alternative or additional costs that will be paid as it’s being cast such as buyback or kicker costs (see rules 117.8 and 117.9), the player announces his or her intentions to pay any or all of those costs (see rule 601.2f). A player can’t apply two alternative methods of casting or two alternative costs to a single spell. If the spell has a variable cost that will be paid as it’s being cast (such as an {X} in its mana cost; see rule 107.3), the player announces the value of that variable. new_start If the value of that variable is defined in the text of the spell by a choice that player would make later in the announcement or resolution of the spell, that player makes that choice at this time instead of that later time. new_end If a cost that will be paid as the spell is being cast includes hybrid mana symbols, the player announces the nonhybrid equivalent cost he or she intends to pay. If a cost that will be paid as the spell is being cast includes Phyrexian mana symbols, the player announces whether he or she intends to pay 2 life or the corresponding colored mana cost for each of those symbols. Previously made choices (such as choosing to cast a spell with flashback from a graveyard or choosing to cast a creature with morph face down) may restrict the player’s options when making these choices.

old.ruleText: Triggered abilities have a trigger condition and an effect. They are written as old_start “[Trigger condition], [effect],” and begin with the word “when,” “whenever,” or “at.” They can also be expressed as old_end “[When/Whenever/At] [trigger event], [effect].”

new.ruleText: Triggered abilities have a trigger condition and an effect. They are written as “[When/Whenever/At] [trigger new_start condition or new_end event], [effect].”

old.ruleText: When a phase or step begins, old_start any old_end abilities that trigger “at the beginning of” that phase or step old_start are added to the stack. old_end

new.ruleText: When a phase or step begins, new_start all new_end abilities that trigger “at the beginning of” that phase or step new_start trigger. new_end

old.ruleText: An ability triggers only once each time its trigger event occurs. However, it can trigger repeatedly if one event contains multiple occurrences. old_start See also rule 509.4. old_end

new.ruleText: An ability triggers only once each time its trigger event occurs. However, it can trigger repeatedly if one event contains multiple occurrences.

old.ruleText: Enters–the–battlefield abilities trigger when a permanent enters the battlefield. These are written, “When [this object] enters the battlefield, . . . old_start ” old_end or “Whenever a [type] enters the battlefield, . . .” Each time an event puts one or more permanents onto the battlefield, all permanents on the battlefield (including the newcomers) are checked for any enters–the–battlefield triggers that match the event.

new.ruleText: Enters–the–battlefield abilities trigger when a permanent enters the battlefield. These are written, “When [this object] enters the battlefield, . . . new_start “ new_end or “Whenever a [type] enters the battlefield, . . .” Each time an event puts one or more permanents onto the battlefield, all permanents on the battlefield (including the newcomers) are checked for any enters–the–battlefield triggers that match the event.

old.ruleText: If an object has an activated or triggered ability printed on it that puts one or more objects onto the battlefield and an ability printed on it that refers to objects “put onto the battlefield with [this object],” those abilities are linked. The second can refer only to objects put onto the battlefield as a result of the first.

new.ruleText: If an object has an activated or triggered ability printed on it that puts one or more objects onto the battlefield and an ability printed on it that refers to objects “put onto the battlefield with [this new_start object]” or “created with [this new_end object],” those abilities are linked. The second can refer only to objects put onto the battlefield as a result of the first.

old.ruleText: If an effect requires a player to choose a source of damage, he or she may choose a permanent; a spell on the stack (including a permanent spell); any object referred to by an object on the stack, by a replacement or prevention effect that’s waiting to apply, or by a delayed triggered ability that’s waiting to trigger (even if that object is no longer in the zone it used to be in); old_start or, for certain casual variant games, old_end a face–up old_start card old_end in the command zone. A source doesn’t need to be capable of dealing damage to be a legal choice. The source is chosen when the effect is created. If the player chooses a permanent, the effect will apply to the next damage dealt by that permanent, regardless of whether it’s combat damage or damage dealt as the result of a spell or ability. If the player chooses a permanent spell, the effect will apply to any damage dealt by that spell and any damage dealt by the permanent that spell becomes when it resolves.

new.ruleText: If an effect requires a player to choose a source of damage, he or she may choose a permanent; a spell on the stack (including a permanent spell); any object referred to by an object on the stack, by a replacement or prevention effect that’s waiting to apply, or by a delayed triggered ability that’s waiting to trigger (even if that object is no longer in the zone it used to be in); new_start or new_end a face–up new_start object new_end in the command zone. A source doesn’t need to be capable of dealing damage to be a legal choice. The source is chosen when the effect is created. If the player chooses a permanent, the effect will apply to the next damage dealt by that permanent, regardless of whether it’s combat damage or damage dealt as the result of a spell or ability. If the player chooses a permanent spell, the effect will apply to any damage dealt by that spell and any damage dealt by the permanent that spell becomes when it resolves.

old.ruleText: A one–shot effect does something just once and doesn’t have a duration. Examples include dealing damage, destroying a permanent, old_start putting old_end a old_start token onto the battlefield, old_end and moving an object from one zone to another.

new.ruleText: A one–shot effect does something just once and doesn’t have a duration. Examples include dealing damage, destroying a permanent, new_start creating new_end a new_start token, new_end and moving an object from one zone to another.
If multiple one–shot effects are created this way immediately after one or more simultaneous events, those one–shot effects are also simultaneous.

old.ruleText: Effects that read “[This permanent] enters the battlefield with . . . ,” “As [this permanent] enters the battlefield . . . ,” or “[This permanent] enters the battlefield as . . . old_start ” old_end are replacement effects.

new.ruleText: Effects that read “[This permanent] enters the battlefield with . . . ,” “As [this permanent] enters the battlefield . . . ,” or “[This permanent] enters the battlefield as . . . new_start “ new_end are replacement effects.

old.ruleText: One card (Apocalypse Chime) refers to permanents with the same name as a card originally printed in the Homelands™ expansion. Those cards are Abbey Gargoyles; Abbey Matron; old_start Æther old_end Storm; Aliban’s Tower; Ambush; Ambush Party; Anaba Ancestor; Anaba Bodyguard; Anaba Shaman; Anaba Spirit Crafter; An–Havva Constable; An–Havva Inn; An–Havva Township; An–Zerrin Ruins; Apocalypse Chime; Autumn Willow; Aysen Abbey; Aysen Bureaucrats; Aysen Crusader; Aysen Highway; Baki’s Curse; Baron Sengir; Beast Walkers; Black Carriage; Broken Visage; Carapace; Castle Sengir; Cemetery Gate; Chain Stasis; Chandler; Clockwork Gnomes; Clockwork Steed; Clockwork Swarm; Coral Reef; Dark Maze; Daughter of Autumn; Death Speakers; Didgeridoo; Drudge Spell; Dry Spell; Dwarven Pony; Dwarven Sea Clan; Dwarven Trader; Ebony Rhino; Eron the Relentless; Evaporate; Faerie Noble; Feast of the Unicorn; Feroz’s Ban; Folk of An–Havva; Forget; Funeral March; Ghost Hounds; Giant Albatross; Giant Oyster; Grandmother Sengir; Greater Werewolf; Hazduhr the Abbot; Headstone; Heart Wolf; Hungry Mist; Ihsan’s Shade; Irini Sengir; Ironclaw Curse; Jinx; Joven; Joven’s Ferrets; Joven’s Tools; Koskun Falls; Koskun Keep; Labyrinth Minotaur; Leaping Lizard; Leeches; Mammoth Harness; Marjhan; Memory Lapse; Merchant Scroll; Mesa Falcon; Mystic Decree; Narwhal; Orcish Mine; Primal Order; Prophecy; Rashka the Slayer; Reef Pirates; Renewal; Retribution; Reveka, Wizard Savant; Root Spider; Roots; Roterothopter; Rysorian Badger; Samite Alchemist; Sea Sprite; Sea Troll; Sengir Autocrat; Sengir Bats; Serra Aviary; Serra Bestiary; Serra Inquisitors; Serra Paladin; Serrated Arrows; Shrink; Soraya the Falconer; Spectral Bears; Timmerian Fiends; Torture; Trade Caravan; Truce; Veldrane of Sengir; Wall of Kelp; Willow Faerie; Willow Priestess; Winter Sky; and Wizards’ School.

new.ruleText: One card (Apocalypse Chime) refers to permanents with the same name as a card originally printed in the Homelands™ expansion. Those cards are Abbey Gargoyles; Abbey Matron; new_start Aether new_end Storm; Aliban’s Tower; Ambush; Ambush Party; Anaba Ancestor; Anaba Bodyguard; Anaba Shaman; Anaba Spirit Crafter; An–Havva Constable; An–Havva Inn; An–Havva Township; An–Zerrin Ruins; Apocalypse Chime; Autumn Willow; Aysen Abbey; Aysen Bureaucrats; Aysen Crusader; Aysen Highway; Baki’s Curse; Baron Sengir; Beast Walkers; Black Carriage; Broken Visage; Carapace; Castle Sengir; Cemetery Gate; Chain Stasis; Chandler; Clockwork Gnomes; Clockwork Steed; Clockwork Swarm; Coral Reef; Dark Maze; Daughter of Autumn; Death Speakers; Didgeridoo; Drudge Spell; Dry Spell; Dwarven Pony; Dwarven Sea Clan; Dwarven Trader; Ebony Rhino; Eron the Relentless; Evaporate; Faerie Noble; Feast of the Unicorn; Feroz’s Ban; Folk of An–Havva; Forget; Funeral March; Ghost Hounds; Giant Albatross; Giant Oyster; Grandmother Sengir; Greater Werewolf; Hazduhr the Abbot; Headstone; Heart Wolf; Hungry Mist; Ihsan’s Shade; Irini Sengir; Ironclaw Curse; Jinx; Joven; Joven’s Ferrets; Joven’s Tools; Koskun Falls; Koskun Keep; Labyrinth Minotaur; Leaping Lizard; Leeches; Mammoth Harness; Marjhan; Memory Lapse; Merchant Scroll; Mesa Falcon; Mystic Decree; Narwhal; Orcish Mine; Primal Order; Prophecy; Rashka the Slayer; Reef Pirates; Renewal; Retribution; Reveka, Wizard Savant; Root Spider; Roots; Roterothopter; Rysorian Badger; Samite Alchemist; Sea Sprite; Sea Troll; Sengir Autocrat; Sengir Bats; Serra Aviary; Serra Bestiary; Serra Inquisitors; Serra Paladin; Serrated Arrows; Shrink; Soraya the Falconer; Spectral Bears; Timmerian Fiends; Torture; Trade Caravan; Truce; Veldrane of Sengir; Wall of Kelp; Willow Faerie; Willow Priestess; Winter Sky; and Wizards’ School.
To create one or more tokens with certain characteristics, put the specified number of tokens with the specified characteristics onto the battlefield.

Previously, an effect that created tokens instructed a player to “put [those tokens] onto the battlefield.” Cards that were printed with that text have received errata in the Oracle card reference so they now “create” those tokens.
If cards in a player’s library are shuffled or otherwise reordered, any revealed cards that are reordered stop being revealed and become new objects.
Some effects instruct a player to look at one or more cards. Looking at a card follows the same rules as revealing a card, except that the card is shown only to the specified player.

A player may planeswalk as the result of the “planeswalking ability” (see rule 901.8), because the owner of a face–up plane card or phenomenon card leaves the game (see rule 901.10), or because a phenomenon’s triggered ability leaves the stack (see rule 704.5x). Abilities may also instruct a player to planeswalk.
If a spell or ability instructs a player to transform a permanent, and the face that permanent would transform into is represented by an instant or sorcery card face, nothing happens.

old.ruleText: To populate means to choose a creature token you control and old_start put old_end a token old_start onto the battlefield old_end that’s a copy of that creature token.

new.ruleText: To populate means to choose a creature token you control and new_start create new_end a token that’s a copy of that creature token.

old.ruleText: If you control no creature tokens when instructed to populate, you won’t old_start put old_end a old_start token onto the battlefield. old_end

new.ruleText: If you control no creature tokens when instructed to populate, you won’t new_start create new_end a new_start token. new_end

old.ruleText: “Investigate” means old_start “Put old_end a colorless Clue artifact token old_start onto the battlefield. It has old_end ‘{2}, Sacrifice this artifact: Draw a card.’”

new.ruleText: “Investigate” means new_start “Create new_end a colorless Clue artifact token new_start with new_end ‘{2}, Sacrifice this artifact: Draw a card.’”
If an effect refers to a “[keyword ability] cost,” it refers only to the variable costs for that keyword.

old.ruleText: You can’t cast a card face old_start down if it doesn’t have a old_end morph old_start ability. old_end

new.ruleText: You can’t new_start normally new_end cast a card face new_start down. A new_end morph new_start ability allows you to do so. new_end
While determining if you could begin to cast a card with suspend, take into consideration any effects that would prohibit that card from being cast.

old.ruleText: Living weapon is a triggered ability. “Living weapon” means “When this Equipment enters the battlefield, old_start put old_end a 0/0 black Germ creature old_start token onto the battlefield, old_end then attach this Equipment to it.”

new.ruleText: Living weapon is a triggered ability. “Living weapon” means “When this Equipment enters the battlefield, new_start create new_end a 0/0 black Germ creature new_start token, new_end then attach this Equipment to it.”

old.ruleText: Myriad is a triggered ability that may also create a delayed triggered ability. “Myriad” means “Whenever this creature attacks, for each opponent other than defending player, you may old_start put old_end a token that’s a copy of this creature old_start onto the battlefield old_end tapped and attacking that player or a planeswalker he or she controls. If old_start you put old_end one or more tokens old_start onto the battlefield old_end this way, exile the tokens at end of combat.”

new.ruleText: Myriad is a triggered ability that may also create a delayed triggered ability. “Myriad” means “Whenever this creature attacks, for each opponent other than defending player, you may new_start create new_end a token that’s a copy of this creature new_start that’s new_end tapped and attacking that player or a planeswalker he or she controls. If one or more tokens new_start are created new_end this way, exile the tokens at end of combat.”

Crew is an activated ability of Vehicle cards. “Crew N” means “Tap any number of untapped creatures you control with total power N or greater: This permanent becomes an artifact creature until end of turn.”
A creature “crews a Vehicle” when it’s tapped to pay the cost to activate a Vehicle’s crew ability.
If an effect states that a creature “can’t crew Vehicles,” that creature can’t be tapped to pay the crew cost of a Vehicle.

Fabricate is a triggered ability. “Fabricate N” means “When this permanent enters the battlefield, you may put N +1/+1 counters on it. If you don’t, create N 1/1 colorless Servo artifact creature tokens.”
If a permanent has multiple instances of fabricate, each triggers separately.

old.ruleText: Some objects become or turn another object into a “copy” of a spell, permanent, or card. Some effects old_start put old_end a token old_start onto the battlefield old_end that’s a copy of another object. (Certain older cards were printed with the phrase “search for a copy.” This section doesn’t cover those cards, which have received new text in the Oracle card reference.)

new.ruleText: Some objects become or turn another object into a “copy” of a spell, permanent, or card. Some effects new_start create new_end a token that’s a copy of another object. (Certain older cards were printed with the phrase “search for a copy.” This section doesn’t cover those cards, which have received new text in the Oracle card reference.)

old.ruleText: If a player casts a split card with fuse from his or her hand, in addition to choosing either half as described above, the player may choose to cast both halves, resulting in a fused split old_start spell. Both halves are old_end evaluated to see if old_start the spell old_end can be cast. old_start If either half can’t be cast, then both halves can’t be cast as a single spell. old_end

new.ruleText: If a player casts a split card with fuse from his or her hand, in addition to choosing either half as described above, the player may choose to cast both halves, resulting in a fused split new_start spell with the combined characteristics of both halves. Only the fused split spell is new_end evaluated to see if new_start it new_end can be cast.

If an effect needs to know the number of objects that changed zones, a melded permanent among those objects counts as one object that moved. If the effect needs to know the number of cards that changed zones, that melded permanent counts as two cards that moved.

old.ruleText: If the monarch leaves the game, the active player becomes the monarch at the same time as that player leaves the game. If the leaving old_start monarch old_end is old_start the old_end active player, the next player in turn order becomes the monarch.

new.ruleText: If the monarch leaves the game, the active player becomes the monarch at the same time as that player leaves the game. If the new_start active player is new_end leaving new_start the game or if there new_end is new_start no new_end active player, the next player in turn order becomes the monarch.

old.ruleText: If an object would change to the control of a player who has left the game, it doesn’t. If a token would old_start enter the battlefield old_end under the control of a player who has left the game, no token is created. If a player would be controlled by a player who has left the game, he or she isn’t.

new.ruleText: If an object would change to the control of a player who has left the game, it doesn’t. If a token would new_start be created new_end under the control of a player who has left the game, no token is created. new_start If an object would be put onto the battlefield or onto the stack under the control of a player who has left the game, that object remains in its current zone. new_end If a player would be controlled by a player who has left the game, he or she isn’t.
